alert.note: Alert for Central Highlands; Chaves County Plains; Curry County; De Baca County; East Slopes Sangre de Cristo Mountains; Eastern Lincoln County; Eastern San Miguel County; Estancia Valley; Far Northeast Highlands; Glorieta Mesa Including Glorieta Pass; Guadalupe County; Harding County; Johnson and Bartlett Mesas Including Raton Pass; Northeast Highlands; Northern Sangre de Cristo Mountains; Quay County; Roosevelt County; Sandia, Manzano Mountains Including Edgewood; South Central Highlands; South Central Mountains; Southern Sangre de Cristo Mountains; Southwest Chaves County; Union County (New Mexico) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Albuquerque (Northern and Central New Mexico)
info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued November 17 at 2:30PM MST by NWS Albuquerque
info.description: ...ARCTIC AIR TO INVADE EASTERN NEW MEXICO TONIGHT INTO FRIDAY AND SATURDAY... Cold air from the Arctic will race southward down the plains late today into early Friday. Temperatures have already been running colder than average the past few days, and this Arctic front will send temperatures tumbling even further. Chilly overnight temperatures ranging from the teens to the low 20`s will be common across eastern New Mexico tonight, with some single digit lows showing up for Friday night. Daytime highs on Friday will remain below freezing for most of this area. Breezy to occasionally windy conditions will make it feel even colder with frigid wind chills in the single digits and teens. In addition to the colder air, areas of light wintry precipitation and freezing fog are expected to develop across eastern New Mexico tonight into Friday. This will include light snow, mainly for northeastern New Mexico, and also areas of freezing drizzle. The freezing fog, light snow and freezing drizzle will all be capable of producing slick road surfaces that could produce hazardous travel conditions. Those who are planning to travel across eastern New Mexico should plan accordingly and be prepared for slower driving speeds that will require more time to reach your destination. Ensure your vehicle is winterized and take inventory of emergency preparedness items. Dress appropriately for the colder weather with several layers of loose-fitting clothing along with mittens and a hat. You can stay informed of the latest weather forecast at weather.gov/abq and you can find the latest road conditions at nmroads.com
